quote: Where have you been Rashella? Zena and Aran are waiting to take Alexandra.
No.
No? I told you...
No, Radue. They can't have her.
I will never let her go.

Captain's log, supplemental. We remain in orbit around Aldea. It's becoming all too evident that talk will not effect the return of our children. We must neutralize the Aldean shield. Until then we are helpless.
Sir, Radue is hailing us.
Captain Picard.
Doctor Crusher and I are ready, Radue.
Are you ill, Captain?
No. Doctor Crusher is a Staff Officer, Radue. Starfleet Regulation 6.57 requires at least two staff officers to be present during any treaty or contract negotiations.
Very well.
Not much on pleasantries, is he?
I am not aware of Regulation 6.57, sir.
Neither am I, Data.
Oh. I see.
Doctor Crusher, report to the bridge... Now we'll see what they have in mind.
Over here, Wesley.
Custodian, Wesley Crusher's voice will be entered into the authorized file -- for Third Level clearance.
Proceed, Duana.
Announce yourself to the Custodian.
Hello, Custodian. I'm Wesley Crusher.
Hello, Wesley. Your voice will now activate Third Level clearance.
Thank you. What does that mean?
You may ask any questions you wish.
Thank you. Duana, what does the Custodian do?
It frees us from all burden. It takes care of all our needs. It regulates our lives.
Who built it?
The Progenitors.
When?
Before my time. Centuries ago.
... What's its power source?
Wesley, why is that important? It does what we ask it. It always has. What difference does it make how it works?
If you don't know how it works, how can you repair it?
(not understanding the concept) Why would we want to repair it?
From time to time, every computer -- I mean Custodian -- requires maintainance.
Wesley, Radue is right. You ask questions I can't answer. Ask the Custodian instead.
Custodian, can you show me where Harry is?
Yes.
Show me Harry.
I never did this before. It's fun.
You are going to make Harry into a sculptor?
He already is. He has just never been encouraged properly. The tool Leda is giving him will allow him to bring out his visions.
It will take years for him to learn to do that.
Oh, no. It will happen quite quickly.
Custodian, show me Alexandra.
Custodian, show me Jason...
Stop, Custodian.
We must work now... there is much to learn.
What's in there?
It's probably the power source.
I don't know. It's forbidden. The Custodian allows no one in there. There's no one left who's authorized.
Open hailing frequency, Lieutenant Yar.
Open, sir.
Ah, good. You're ready.
I want to see the children before we begin.
No. We're here to negotiate for compensation, not to pander to emotions. This way.
Radue, we do not condone your actions. You're attempting to salve your conscience by offering goods in exchange for our children.
Why do you want them back so badly? You can always make more.
We happen to like these particular children.
Humans have great attachment to their offspring. But we're digressing. Returning the children is non-negotiable.
I promise you they will have a beautiful life with us. And they'll be father and mother to a new breed born of an ancient culture.
What makes you think they'll be able to have children? You can't.
But they will. Our inability to bear children is a genetic dysfunction. It's not contagious.
Radue, we do sympathize. But surely there is a solution which can be mutually satisfactory.
For us, the problem is solved. We are offering you information on areas of the galaxy you don't even know exist. What more can we offer? What more would you want?
A significant beginning, I think. But first I must ask again that Doctor Crusher be allowed to speak with her son before we continue.
You are a very stubborn people. Ah, well, that can be a positive trait. You may see him.
Mom!
I knew the captain would get us home.
Not yet, Wes.
Oh. I thought... never mind.
Are you okay? And the others?
Okay, really okay. Everyone's been assigned their own units... you know, like families. We're being treated, well, almost like gods.
Don't let it go to your head.
I won't.
So, what have you been doing?

I'm learning a lot. They have a computer which they call the Custodian. It controls everything. The captain should know this. All their defense systems, the city's environment, everything. And it's all voice command. So simple. But the amazing thing is the Aldeans don't know how it works. They know how to talk to it, but they don't even know what its power source is, and they didn't do the original programming.
(continuing; normal voice) They said that later on, when I'm really an Aldean, I'll know all their secrets.
That won't happen, Wes. I promise I won't let that happen.
You must leave, Doctor Crusher.
Take care of yourself.
I will, Mom.
Wes seems fine. He says the other children are too.
Of course they're well.
Captain Picard, you have our offer. It is final. Rashella.
Captain, we want you to understand the nature of your choice. A small demonstration of our power...
What was that?
I believe it was a repulsor beam, sir.
Position report.
It's unbelievable, sir. According to my calculations, we're three days from Aldea -- at warp nine.
They call that a "small" Demonstration?
Geordi, take us back to Aldea orbit. Warp factor nine.
Captain, if you don't accept our terms, the Enterprise will be pushed so far away, by the time you get back, your children will be grandparents.

Captain's log, stardate 41509.45. We are twenty hours away from Aldea, and no closer to a solution. Their deliberate show of force pushed us out of orbit and could have disintegrated the ship. In the face of that power, a direct assault on Aldea would be disastrous.
Now, hold it a little bit more firmly.
That's it. Perfect. Now... think. No, think's not right. Feel the notes inside your head.
I'm sorry! Did I break it?
No. It's all right. You can't break it.
It did exactly what I thought... I mean, felt.
Yes. It's a direct expression of the music within. Now we just have to teach you to structure that feeling...
That was beautiful. Now play something happier.
(sadly shaking her head) That's not how I feel. I don't want to do this anymore.
You see, Harry, I told you you were going to be an artist.
Are you sure? Did I really do this?
Oh, yes. Your talent has always been there. The sculpting tool is just helping you develop it. It's what you were meant to do.
You mean I don't have to do calculus anymore?
You don't have to do anything you don't want to do. What's calculus?
Nothing important. Can I do some more?
Captain's log, supplemental. It has been three days since the Aldeans pushed us away. We have had no contact with Radue since then.
Lieutenant Yar, open hailing frequencies.
Frequencies open, sir.
Radue, this is Captain Picard.
Welcome back, Captain. What have you decided?
There is room for discussion, Radue.
We will bring you down when we are ready.
Data, find a way to defeat that shield.
That may be impossible, sir.
Things are impossible, until they're not.
Yes, sir.
Captain, here's what I've learned. Duana is dying. I have no reason to believe the rest of the Aldeans are any healthier.
We're all dying, Doctor. Can you be more specific?
They're suffering from some kind of chromosomal damage. It could be genetic, or environmental.
Then that's why they can't conceive.
Yes. It also explains their lack of appetite, their sensitivity to light, and their extreme pallor.
An entire civilization that's terminally ill... is it reversible?
I won't know until I've found the cause... and you don't need to tell me time is running out.
Good work, Doctor.
I thought growing boys are always hungry.
You didn't eat anything.
We need very little.
I know you miss your family. But you will grow accustomed to us. I promise. I promise you'll be happy.
You can keep me here, but you can't make me want to stay. You'll never be able to make me forget. And I'll never be an Aldean.
Have the lesions gone?
Yes. The medicine worked again.
Good. Come see what Harry's doing.
Beautiful!
It really turned out well.
It is so graceful and alive. What do you call it?
It's a dolphin.
Dolphin?
You know, it swims in the ocean. Like a fish, only it's not a fish.
Ah. A fish. We used to have them in our oceans. I've never seen one before.
I used to live near the ocean. On Zadar IV. My dad's an oceanographer. He says... never mind. It doesn't matter.
No. That doesn't fit the pattern. Give me a list of the appropriate medical literature from the twenty-second century.
There's not enough time!
Is there anything I can do?
You just did, Jean-Luc. Now... I have to get back to work.
I want Mommy!
Custodian's room.
Custodian, this is Wesley Crusher.
Proceed, Wesley.
Show me where all the Enterprise children are in relation to this room.
Thank you.
Custodian, what's your instruction set?
How can I command your attention? Do you have a non-maskable interrupt?
Yes.
What is its address?
Zero, twelve, twenty-two, twenty-one, twenty-three, twenty-six.
That doesn't make any sense to me.
Custodian, what's in the locked room next to this one?
You are not authorized for that information.
Thank you. Good night.
Good night, Wesley.
I need your help. I have an idea how we can get home.
Why will not talking or eating make them send us home?
scene: 63   INT. ALDEA - WESLEY'S ROOM - EARLY MORNING

quote: It's called "passive resistance." We don't do anything they want us to do and then they won't want us.
scene: 63   INT. ALDEA - WESLEY'S ROOM - EARLY MORNING

quote: Will they get mad at us?
scene: 63   INT. ALDEA - WESLEY'S ROOM - EARLY MORNING

quote: They won't hurt us.
scene: 63   INT. ALDEA - WESLEY'S ROOM - EARLY MORNING

quote: But, Wes, I do kind of like them.
scene: 63   INT. ALDEA - WESLEY'S ROOM - EARLY MORNING

quote: So do I, but I don't want to stay here forever. Do you?
scene: 63   INT. ALDEA - WESLEY'S ROOM - EARLY MORNING

quote: No, but I like working with the wood.
scene: 63   INT. ALDEA - WESLEY'S ROOM - EARLY MORNING

quote: Harry, we all have to do this together or it won't work.
scene: 63   INT. ALDEA - WESLEY'S ROOM - EARLY MORNING

quote: Okay. I'll do it.
scene: 63   INT. ALDEA - WESLEY'S ROOM - EARLY MORNING

quote: What are you all doing here together?
scene: 63   INT. ALDEA - WESLEY'S ROOM - EARLY MORNING

quote: What is going on here?
scene: 63   INT. ALDEA - WESLEY'S ROOM - EARLY MORNING

quote: Garen!
scene: 63   INT. ALDEA - WESLEY'S ROOM - EARLY MORNING

quote: Take the children back to their units.
scene: 63   INT. ALDEA - WESLEY'S ROOM - EARLY MORNING

quote: The Aldeans are suffering from a form of radiation poisoning.
And that's what's made the Aldeans sterile?
Yes.
Is it reversible?
Of course.
Captain, these permutations are going to take a very long time.
How long?
Weeks.
Captain, there is another option. We have identified a weakness in the shield.
But it's not constant.
It's a hole.
It's not a hole as much as it is a fluctuation.
Still, there is a chance. Captain, if we can time it exactly -- I think we can beam a team through the hole and onto the planet.
Then why can't we beam the children up through the hole?
The timing would be more difficult, and the risk greater.
What are you suggesting, Number One?
Beam through the hole. Locate the source of the shield, and knock it out.
I'll try to delay the Aldeans until you're ready.
Will you at least eat?
I know you're hungry. We all are, but Alexandra, we are not going to eat anything. It's our way of telling them that we want to go home. Do you understand?
Captain Picard. You may come down now to conclude our discussion, or your ship may leave. It is your choice.
We are ready, Captain.
Doctor Crusher and I are prepared to conclude these negotiations.
Transporter room, now!
Energize.
Before we begin, Captain, you must speak with the children. It seems they are on some sort of "strike." I don't understand it. You must deal with this, Captain. I'm not very good with children.
A strike? I'll see what I can do.
Sir! We knew you'd come!
It's not over yet, Wesley.
Captain, I think I figured out their computer controls -- I'm not sure, it's a different system than ours.
Good, Wesley. Now...
...Captain.
Yes, Harry.
If something happens and you have to leave us here -- tell my Dad... I'm sorry I made him angry... and I miss him.
I will tell him, Harry, and I will tell him how much I admire his son.
This is it, Commander.
It is programmed to accept only authorized voice commands.
So we can't override.
No. But I can intermix the input so nobody else can.
We must find the power supply for the shield.
What is this?
They want to go home.
No. They're staying.
Number One.
We are in position.
Hold for orders.
Aye, sir.

The radiation levels on Aldea have built up over a long period of time. It is similar to what was experienced on Earth in the twenty-first century, when the ozone layer deteriorated and the surface of the planet was flooded with ultraviolet radiation.
The shield that protects your world in one way has weakened it in another. It's the radiation of your own sun which is destroying you.
You are trying to confuse the issue.
Please listen. You're all suffering from a kind of poisoning. Sterility is only the latest symptom. If the children remain, they will be affected as well.
It is impossible. Our scientists would have known.
How could they? Your scientists have forgotten how everything works.
No. It's a lie. Send them back to their ship.
Wait. No. What if they're right? Instead of the children being our hope, what if we are just condeming them to our fate?
They are just protecting their own interests.

As are we. But hear them out. The captain and Doctor Crusher are saying our entire life is based on a misconception, and the very thing which has given us this wonderful world is the very thing which has caused this tragedy?
That is exactly it. The shield that protects you, has weakened and your computer has controlled your lives so completely you've lost the desire to even question it.
Lies. The discussion is over.
Commander Riker.
Yes, sir.
I assume you have control of the computer.
We've disabled the system temporarily and we've found the power source to the shield and we've neutralized it.
Good. Enterprise, this is Picard. Beam the children up.
Wait.
Thank you.
Let me get the dolphin for you to take with you.
No. You keep it. I'll make another.
Beam them up.
You've destroyed us.
We are not here to destroy you, Radue. We can help you.
What is it?
The legacy your Progenitors left you, Radue. The source of your power. And your problems.
It is reading incredible amounts of energy, sir. Even more since we have taken down the shield.
What are we going to do with it?
Learn all over again... all this time we've been destroying ourselves. So secure, so sure of our technological invulnerability. Now...
Will you let us help?
Yes. Please.
Dad, I want to be an artist. And I don't want to take calculus anymore.
You can be anything you want, Harry. Anything. But you still have to take calculus.
Okay. Thanks, Dad.
It worked well, sir.
Are you finished?
Yes. They're responding very well to the treatment, but for this to work, they can never use their shield or be cloaked again.
The legend will die, but the people will live.
And we know they'll make good parents.
Wesley!
Sorry, sir. She just wanted to give you a present for bringing her back to her mommy.
Mister La Forge, out of orbit. Warp five.
Yes, sir. Certainly, sir.
Captain's log, Stardate 42502.7. We are traveling in the Omega Twelve System traversing between a clustering of small planets that form the coalition of Madena VI.
Each of these planets is populated by separate humanoid people who co-exist and trade technology and minerals under a precarious but successful treaty.
We have an unidentified vessel approaching.
Give me grid markers.
Sector three-nine-five-six, mark zero-nine-one.
Sensor readings place overall dimension of vehicle an interplanetary cargo ship.
One life sign on board, appears to be humanoid.
A vessel of that size usually maintains a crew of six.
Minimum armament present.
Sensors show cargo holds are empty.
The course is inconsistent with normal cargo routes.
This could be a primitive method to elude detection.
Readout shows a burnout in inertial guidance system...
The pilot is attempting to hold his vessel in check manually.
That could be a pretense.

Captain's log, supplemental. We have just encountered and identified an interplanetary cargo vessel which is apparently in need of emergency assistance. We will make every effort to do so. Open hailing frequencies.
Hailing frequencies open.
This is the USS Enterprise. Captain Jean-Luc Picard, over.

And this is the cargo ship Erstwhile "limping" and "skidding" off course. Captain Okona at your service. As you see, there is no need for phasers, Captain. I'm harmless and not quite ready yet for mercy killing.
You were never considered a danger to us, Captain Okona.
It's a shame. I can remember when I was at least considered a "risk."
The ship is in viewer range now, Captain.
Main Viewer on.
I'm the owner and operator of this craft and since we both know you scanned my vessel, you know I'm alone and empty... ... and it's truly a rare occasion for a man of my charm, beauty and talent.
But then with the condition of this vessel I'm glad I have no responsibilities except for myself till I can get some repairs.
Counselor, can you read him?
His emotions suggest that he is mischievous, irreverent and somewhat brazen. And some other things... The word that seems to describe him best is "rogue."
Rogue? Accessing "rogue." Cad, knave, rake, rascal, scoundrel, villain.
Yes, all of that, but he shows no malevolence, or ill will.
What form of assistance can we offer you, Captain?
I had a burnout on my guidance system. I'd appreciate it if I could use your facilities to repair it.
It would be possible.
Estimate, Mister Data.
Time for repair would be seven hours sixteen minutes.
Okona will have to shut down while we verify specifications.
Lieutenant Worf, prepare security procedures. We can accommodate you.
I'll allow him limited access.
If you'll prepare to shut down your engines we'll lock on tractors and beam you aboard.
Many thanks, Captain Picard.
Transporter Chief, prepare to beam aboard from Tractor lock bearing.
Yes Number One, at your command.
Is that a woman's voice I hear?
Yes. Now please follow the directions of Commander Riker so our ship can get back to its normal routine.
Something funny, Commander Riker.
The unexpected, like what's happening now, IS our normal routine.
Hold it steady, Wesley. We're ready to link up. On my command...
scene: 10   EXT. SPACE - THE ENTERPRISE / THE ERSTWHILE (OPTICAL)

quote: Aye Number One.
scene: 10   EXT. SPACE - THE ENTERPRISE / THE ERSTWHILE (OPTICAL)

quote: Easy... easy... Engage. Shut down engines, Captain Okona.
scene: 10   EXT. SPACE - THE ENTERPRISE / THE ERSTWHILE (OPTICAL)

quote: Transporter Room proceed with Beaming Operation. I'm on my way.
Yes, Commander.
Your weapons, please.
You're the tough one on this ship. The muscle man.
Security.
That's the usual name for warriors nowadays.
It's more of a piece of jewelry than a weapon. A remembrance.
It will be returned when you leave.
Welcome aboard, Captain Okona. I'm Commander Riker. If you turn over the inoperative part to Lieutenant La Forge he'll begin repairs.
I'd be most happy to do the work myself, I'm sort of a "hands on" type...
That will not be permitted.
Can I at least watch? Maybe offer some suggestions?
I think that could be arranged...
Here you are, Lieutenant. I leave it in your capable hands.
No, this is Lieutenant La Forge, I'm only an ensign.
Well ensigns have names, don't they?
Wesley... Wesley Crusher..
Nice to meet you Ensign "Wesley Wesley" Crusher.

And thank you for beaming me here and inviting me to see a truly beautiful woman. You have the majestic carriage and loveliness that could surely be traced back to the noble families who once ruled romantic lands with benevolent and tender hands.
I'm sure you said that to many ladies and it was no more true then, than it is now.
Of course, But it's how I say it that's most important. The feeling, the warmth, the attraction I have for you, the attraction that we share.
I haven't heard that approach in years... it is refreshing...
Mister Okona seems to have excellent vision and a healthy libido.
Which could add to the security problem. I'll supervise him closely.
I'm sure you will, Worf.
If you'll follow Lieutenant La Forge, we'll get right to work.
Now isn't that a beautifully formed picture of sex appeal?
I do not know what you mean. I am an android.
Well then... Have you seen any great looking computers lately?
That's a joke. It's funny.
(still oblivious, but covering) Yes, of course it is.
It's the Zelebium contacts that wore down and then fused. Why not replace them with Tricellite?
Tricellite isn't available in this system. It wouldn't be available to me if I have to replace it.
I don't think your spacecraft will outlast the part.
You mean the age of it or the way I fly it?
The stress test shows that you tend to push it beyond its designed capabilities.

Lieutenant La Forge, I've never been told that I'm somewhat reckless in a kinder, or more gentlemanly manner; but since the pattern of my life has relegated me to interplanetary speed deliveries rather than universal exploration, I'm forced to add a flamboyancy and a zest to the doldrums of my existence.
Captain Okona, I don't know whether I'd rather take a flight with you or listen to you talk.
Thank you Ensign Crusher, Crusher.
It's Wesley, Wesley.
I'll make it easy on both of us. I'll just call you Tiger.
Captain Picard is not fond of nicknames.
Your gallant Captain Picard. I'd like to meet him... I'll stroll on the bridge and say hello.
You are not permitted on the bridge. You are restricted to your quarters or the Ten-Forward lounge unless escorted by a crewmember.
I've broken some small rules before.
You do and besides the bells and lights that will go off, our benevolent and kindly Lieutenant Worf will offer you a new kind of greeting.
Well then, would you escort me to C deck?
I'm busy rebuilding your ship.
Then Mister Data sir, I would feel privileged if you allow me to be in your company while you escort me to my destination...
You ever been cold?
No.
How about warm?
The temperature on this vessel is regulated to within a fraction of a degree of the perfect comfort range. I am also able to react to any changes just as a humanoid.
How about drunk? Ever do that?
That is not possible. One moment.
I was correct. I am not designed to react to any synthenol intake but apparently it is possible for me to become intoxicated.
I don't understand that at all.
It seems that I have been adapting some human peculiarities over the last three tours of duty.
What about love?
The act or the emotion?
They're both the same to me.
I believe that deduction to be inaccurate.
Maybe.
Life is like loading twice your cargo weight on your spacecraft... if it's canaries and you can keep half of them flying all the time, you're all right.
Don't you get it?
Get what?
The punch line... The gag... That was a joke I told you.
I still do not understand.
You don't know what a joke is?
Of course I do. A joke is an antic, a caper, mischief, prank, trick, quip, witticism.
That's the dictionary meaning. I'm talking about humor, fun. Do you know what "funny" is?
Is that C-nine-two-nine?
The room to the left. Why?
You probably wouldn't understand that either...
What's the status of the repair?
On schedule. The difficulty is Okona has to be able to repair this part himself next time.
Commander, do you know much about him?
Just that he's an interesting man.
He's a lot more than that. He's a capable engineer.
In a practical sense he's excellent.
We've seen him handle his ship, and he certainly knows how to handle people.
Everything you say is true.
Then why is he what he is?
Why is he operating a cargo route alone rather than being a member of a large organization like we are?
Yes, that's it.
I would say because he chooses to do exactly what he does.
A cargo master?
An ensign in Engineering?
His choice. Someday you'll make yours.
I already have.
Okona is right.
You agree that I am missing a very important human factor.
All I said was I agree with Okona that you never smile or laugh. At least I've never seen you do it. Do you? Ever?
I never knew I had to.
It's not a "had to." Even Captain Picard can't order you to be happy.
But I am not unhappy. I just do not seem to break out in laughter with everyone else when Okona says certain things.
You mean when he tells a joke. That's it, isn't it? You don't have any idea what a joke is.
Of course I do. It is a witticism, a gag, a bon mot, a fluctuation of words which concludes with "trick" ending, it is...

Whoa, slow down. Now Data, there's just you and me here and nobody is going to know what we talked about. My job here places me under some obligations, like a vow of secrecy. I can't repeat anything I hear or see. Now the obligation of the patron is to tell the truth, otherwise I'm being placed under a commitment to keep a secret about "nothing." That's not fair. It's called wasted honor. You understand?
I understand better than you think. You just told me a joke and I am not laughing.
I can see that.
Maybe it was not funny.
It was funny.
How can you be sure?
I've used it before. Everybody else at least smiles. It's you, Data.
I agree. Now what do I do about it?
When most people have trouble, they look to a more intelligent and learned being for assistance. In your case, I'd suggest you go to a bigger computer.
I wish to learn about jokes...
There are books, films, and tapes. But the only animate object would be a comedian.
Show me one of those.
Specify type, please.
Humanoid. One who is able to understand and tell a joke.
Physical or cerebral style.
Show me both.
I will access a list.
That one. RW nine, three, two, one, six -- twentieth century.
Program installation complete, you may enter.
Thank you ladies and gentlemen. And thank you for bringing me here.
I want to know what is funny.
Things that make you laugh are funny?
Nothing makes me laugh, but I still want to do it.
How much time do we have?
Time has no meaning in this instance. It could be endless.
I think we're going to need it all.
I assure you, I am completely trainable and capable of indoctrination. Show me what is funny.
Okay, try this.
Well?
That is considered funny?
It was till a few seconds ago.
You mean if you twist your face, bend over at the waist, mess up your hair, and cross your eyes it is a pretense that would be funny.
I have to admit it's a little ridiculous, but that's part of being funny. Clowns are ridiculous, but they make people laugh. Now try it.
Can you juggle, whistle, sing?

How about write or paint? I have a house that needs painting. It's hard work, but at least you don't have to be funny. Just a strong wrist, a good eye, and an affection for watching water base off-white dry slowly.
I can do everything else that I want to do. I just want to know what is funny. I want to be able to involve myself in other people's laughter. I want to "join in."
We'll try. You have to remember your "body English" and gestures. Now you're going to learn some jokes.
Proceed.
We'll start with some standards... This traveling salesman...
Access faster...
... comes up to his farmhouse and...
Faster. Move to maximum speed.

This gentleman went to see his surgeon and was informed that he needed an operation. The man thought about that and then said, "I would like a second opinion." The doctor said, "Okay, you are ugly too."
Was I funny?
That joke has been funny for over four hundred years. We'll now have a minute's silence for its passing.
I was not funny...
Forget it. Try another joke.
Who was that woman I saw you with?
Lieutenant Commander Data, report to the Main Bridge immediately. I repeat, report to the Main Bridge immediately.
I will be back.
Bring new jokes...
We have an "unidentified" in Sector four.
Unidentified craft Sector four to Sector four two six one. Overtaking us, no response to our hailing.
Open hailing frequencies in all languages and on all channels.
Hailing frequencies open. No response.
Sensors report a minimum range combat craft of the Squadron Class, twenty-six crew.
Captain, they have locked phasers.
Phasers?
Regulations call for a Yellow Alert.
It's too small of a craft to be of any threat to us. Do you agree, Lieutenant Worf?
We could blow it out of space before it could scratch our hull.
And I doubt that they are so primitive that they wouldn't know it. Ensign Crusher, reduce speed to allow them to overtake.
May I ask why, sir?
They show a great deal of courage. Perhaps I would like to show them some respect, or perhaps I'm just curious.
I understand, Captain. Would a "courteous" Yellow Alert apply at this time?
That won't be necessary, Number One. But continue to hail them and prepare for a gentlemanly surrender if needed.
Still no response to our hail.
The "stranger" vessel has slowed and is holding its position.
Captain, we are being hailed.
On screen.
I am Debin of the planet Atlec.
I am Captain Jean-Luc Picard of the USS Enterprise... What is the reason for this aggressive approach?
You are towing a spacecraft of a known criminal.
It was in need of emergency repairs. It was our obligation to assist.
You have a man by the name of Okona aboard. I want him.
On what authority?
He is guilty of crimes committed on the planet Atlec. I expect him to be turned over to my authority immediately.
What crimes?
That is neither important or necessary. I want Okona now!
Captain, we have another Class four armed spacecraft approaching, from the opposite sector...
Another ship from Atlec?
Similar in specifications and capabilities, but a variation in markings and hailing language.
Hold your position, Mister Debin. Cut off Main Screen.
Identify approaching craft.
Sensors indicate it to be a security vessel from the planet Straleb.
We could swat both mosquitoes easily.
Open hailing frequencies.
Hailing frequencies open.
They are returning our hail on the proper channel.
On screen.
I am Secretary Kushell from the Legation of Unity of the planet Straleb.
I am Captain Picard.
We know who you are, Captain Picard. We have been monitoring your communications and we know of the demands made by Debin of the planet Atlec.
Then you know that we intend no hostile interaction with either of you.
You only have to concede to one demand.
The word "demand" has the tone of finality.
It is a word I have chosen. We demand you turn Okona over to us immediately.
Mute the Main Viewer. Lieutenant Worf, Mister Okona to the Main Bridge immediately.
Yes sir.
Engage the screen. The same "demand" has been made by the Atlec legation.
I have no interest in their request. We intend to back up our legal right to Okona.
I'd rather you didn't escalate this situation any further.
You're my son. You obey orders, you do not interfere with them. We are prepared to take Okona by force if we have to. The honor and prestige of this nation are at stake. We are ready to die for that.
We do not intend for that to be at our hand. I will respond to your request shortly -- Main Viewer off.
I have orders to escort you to the Main Bridge immediately.
I'm sure it can wait a few minutes.
Now!!
I'd like that, but I have orders.
Some other time then.
Just remember, it took three armed men to rip me from your arms.
Am I going to meet Captain Picard?
Definitely.
Did I say something funny?
Captain Picard, this is Thadiun Okona.
In there... We'll talk in there...

Mister Okona, you were welcomed on board and given the security of this ship openly and without any undue investigation. In turn the only obligation we placed you under was that you do not come aboard the Enterprise under false pretenses. It seems that you did.
If you mean my "socializing" with the members of the crew?
No, you are free to interact with the members of the crew. First, I'm talking about a man named Debin. Are you familiar with him?
He's from Atlec. I've had dealings with some of his family.
Then perhaps you can explain why his spacecraft is prepared to attack us unless we give him custody of you.
I can't explain.
Then tell me why Kushell of the planet Straleb is demanding the same thing?
Is he here also?
And quite adamant. Now answer please. What crimes have you committed?
I am not a criminal.
Why do these men want you?
I can't say.
You will say. You're on my ship.
It wouldn't be the honorable thing to do. I may be many less than auspicious things, but I am a gentleman. I won't break that code.
They are prepared to attack the Enterprise.
That would be crazy. They wouldn't stand a chance...
Exactly. Then perhaps you could give me some reasons as to why I should consider destroying these people to save you?
I can't think of any right now.
Neither can I.
Put Debin on screen.
Have you made your decision yet, Captain?
No. You've made your requests but you haven't told me why.
It's a personal matter.
I'm afraid that's not good enough.
Not good enough?? You're forcing me to embarrass my family by demanding reasons.
It was Okona... He's been bringing Yanar gifts, flowers, and even poetry for the past five months. He took advantage. Then he left her like this. I want him.
I do sympathize with you. If you will allow me just a little more time.
Why, so you can turn him over to Kushell? You do that and I'll blow his ship away and Okona with it.
You'll be dust before you aim your first missile. I have a perfect right to Okona. He's a thief. He stole the Jewel of Thesia. A national heritage.
A "thing." An "item." My case involves the victimization of a human form. My daughter.
That's him!! I'll have him now.
He's mine.
One at a time. Who accuses me of stealing?
I do, you thief. Me and my son, Benzan. Okona was my son's friend. He took advantage of that friendship to plunder a national treasure.
What do you have to say about that Okona?
Nothing right now. Let them do all the talking.
Gentlemen if you please!
You will get my decision as soon as I can confer with my advisors and in the interest of maintaining peace I am jamming communications between your two ships. Picard out.
Okona, Doctor, Counselor, Lieutenant Worf, Geordi, the conference room if you please. Have Doctor Pulaski join us...
Dishonesty, lust, and now hunger. You really are extremely basic Mister Okona.
Last meals always taste the best and hunger won't make me a better person.
That's probably true.
Neither one of the allegations is considered a capital crime.
I'll never reach either of those planets alive. They have lost too much face over these incidents.
And yet it provides the possibility of even more violence.
You're not afraid of those two or what they can do to you.

It's what I may have to do to them that concerns me. If I turn you over to Debin, I will have to deal with Kushell. If you go to Kushell, I will have Debin to administer to. Or perhaps both of them would decide to attack us. Fatalities could be total.
I hate to have to be the one to say this, but you don't owe me anything.
I'm well aware of that, but it doesn't change anything. Are you innocent, Thadiun Okona?
Innocent? Absolutely not, Captain Picard. I'll make no excuses for my lifestyle. But I have not committed the crimes that I've been accused of or any others similar.
Then my predicament is confirmed.
In that case, Captain, I can't make it any easier on you.

Apparently you've never been concerned about making it easier on anyone... There are two men out there who do not consider this a joke and are willing to face death as a matter of honor. They should be respected, not laughed at.
You seemed to have reached a decision about me, Captain.
Only about what I think you are. What to do about it is still a problem.
I'll help you with it. Stall Debin and Kushell. Give me enough time to get the guidance system re-installed and I'll go on my own.
Their ships are bigger and faster than yours.
You'll still be able to warp away and I'll take care of myself.
How will you get away?
I'll dazzle them with my brilliance and dexterity.
I don't like it.
You have very little choice.
I know. It will be impossible to stall very long.
"Just long enough" is all I need...
What are you going to say to Debin and Kushell?
Anything I have to.
Now you're starting to sound like me, Captain.
Heaven forbid.
Engage Main Viewer.
Ah, gentlemen... If you'll just bear with me, I have a few questions.
Looks like an excellent job. You're quite a craftsman Lieutenant La Forge. How soon will it be finished?
What's the rush? I thought you liked it here.
I did. It stopped liking me. Time for me to disappear.
Where will you go?
A new place, if I make it.
Don't you ever stay anywhere?
Not for a long time.
I know that's the way you want to be and it is your choice, but I don't understand. You like people. Why do you want to be alone all the time?
It's ready. You should be able to install this in less than five minutes.
Like you said Geordi, what's the rush? I have some friends around here.
One moment please, gentlemen. Screen off.
I've used every pretext I could think of. The result is they've aimed their full ordinance at us and are prepared to attack. I can't delay any longer.
I'm not leaving.
We've gone over this before. I thought you made a decision.
Don't worry, I'm not staying either. I've decided to surrender myself to one of them.
Which one?
Put them on screen and place your bets. The odds are two to one...
On screen.
It took long enough. Now when can I have Okona?
I registered my complaint before you. I have first recourse.
Do not delay your decision again. I'm warning you not to do that, Captain Picard.
Yes, both of you are most adept at issuing warnings. Mister Okona has volunteered to deal with this himself.

I'll speak my piece before I walk to your gallows. As I said before I am not a thief. I am also not a character of exceptional good name and reputation; so, as I never chose to become a thief, I have never chosen to become a father either. Given the choice between the two I must say that marriage to the beautiful and affectionate Yanar is a much more pleasant sentence.
So my dear Yanar, if you would do me the honor of becoming my wife I will do everything in my power to make our marriage happy and fruitful.
No! He can't!
My son is right. Okona will not escape me that way.
No, that's not what I mean.
Send him to me. I'll decide his fate.
Why should you decide? Why don't I? Since everybody knows Okona is the father of this child, why should we not allow him to take his rightful place? I accept.
You can't accept!
That's right. Okona is still a thief.
No he's not. Nothing was stolen.
The Jewel of Thesia!
It was not stolen by my friend Okona.
Then where is it?
You could say it was taken into "custody" by the rightful heir, me.
Benzan has a certain flair for the language that is similar to yours.
A little bit of me might have rubbed off on the boy. I didn't think he would let me hang.
You placed great faith in him.
He's a friend...
Why would you steal what would eventually become yours?
To present it to Yanar as my vow of marriage. Yanar is carrying my child.
Yanar said it was Okona's.
You were with both these men?
No, but that's not what is important now. What is important is who I marry.
You'll marry me.
Why should I?
Because I love you.
You waited this long to say that? You almost allowed Okona to be punished, now suddenly you wish to marry me?
I sent the Jewel of Thesia to you with Okona to declare us man and wife. The politics of our fathers would have been settled later.
So Okona does have the jewel.
I ordered him to deliver it!
And waited a little too long to do that also. I won't marry you, Benzan.
Then you'll marry Okona.
I won't marry anyone!

Don't Yanar. You're angry about the embarrassment of all this and maybe the timing and approach is not the most romantic, but I know you love Benzan and I don't want to see you throw away that feeling because we adults do not know how to behave properly.
If Benzan could speak with the same integrity as you do, maybe it would be different.

I carried your messages back and forth for almost six months. I smuggled each of you into the other's homeland. You feel for him the same way he feels for you. So for heaven's sake girl, you have to marry the boy because I've finally run out of words.
I don't believe that.
It is mathematically possible.
Okona defies even the science of mathematics.
Was that funny?
I do love him.
Then tell him.
I'll marry Benzan. It is his child. It's our child.
Then I'll have to withdraw my charges of theft. By our law Benzan must present the jewel to his wife.
I'll be coming for you shortly Yanar. We'll find a new planet to live on.
You'll live on Straleb.
No! You'll live here!
Gentlemen, this is a matter to be settled between yourselves. I have only two words for both of you. Picard out.
Take over, Will. Mister Okona and I are going to drink a toast to the newlyweds.
Weddings bring out emotions in me that I never could quite understand. I get so sentimental.
Perhaps it's the way they drape the flowers over the shotgun that makes you cry.
We could have destroyed both crafts without even using our photon torpedoes. They were totally vulnerable.
Maybe next time, Worf. Maybe next time.
I wish to reinstate the same program.
Maybe with some new material.
We will continue.
What, no warm up?
I told a joke.
And?
No one laughed.
No one? Nobody?
Me, I'm "no one" and "nobody." It wasn't funny.
She said I "killed" the joke.
It's always hard to deal with a solo person. You need a crowd. Laughter is contagious.
A lot of things are contagious. Most of them aren't funny either.
Perhaps he is right. An audience could be the difference. Holodeck, give me an audience.
And now folks from his record breaking tour of Straleb and Atlec I bring you the funny man of the stars, that comet comedian, the sensation of the solar system, ... DATA!
Good evening ladies and "germs."
You know I come from a town so small it had a fraction for a zip code.
... It was so small in fact that it didn't have a Godfather of Crime... it had a Nephew..
You sure you made a living doing this?

I was so ugly as a child they hung a pork chop around my neck so the dog would play with me. Then there was the gene bank where they crossed a lion and a parrot. They weren't sure what they got but when it spoke, they listened.
Or the human cannonball that was hired and fired in the same night.
Holodeck off.
It was a Holodeck audience. They were programmed to laugh at anything...
Never mind that. Let me tell you one about the traveling salesman.
I have heard it... I have heard them all.
Hold the speed, Captain Okona. We'll disengage at my command. Disengage.
Separated.
I'm under my own power. Thank you, Enterprise. Thank you, Captain Picard.
I think it turned out to be "my pleasure," Mister Okona.
You've got a bizarre sense of humor, Captain.
Stretched to the limit with you, but thankfully still present. I think I might miss your presence, but I would like it to remain a fond memory.
Well put Captain Picard, and good-bye sir.
Good-bye Captain Okona.
What about you Data? You can say good-bye, Data.
"Good-bye Data."
Was I funny?
And there is the one about the girl in the nudist colony that nothing looked good on.
Warp speed Captain?
Please...

Captain's log, stardate 41886.9. We are en route to Sarona 8 for much needed R and R. The entire crew is looking forward to the diversion. On a personal note, I have allowed myself the luxury of a head start.
En garde.
I took advantage...
No, no. The advantage was yours, Number One. I'm out of practice... too much time on the bridge. En garde!
Interesting move. What technique was that?
The technique of a desperate man. Shall we...
Yellow Alert.
Picard to bridge. Report.
It is not an attack that we know of, Captain. Origin unknown. Sensors did not detect the force until immediately prior to impact. Shields did not have time to respond. Damages unknown.
We're on our way, Mister Data.
Damage reports from all decks coming in, sir.
Injuries?
Minor.
I still am unable to determine the cause of the energy force. There is nothing within a reasonable distance of this ship powerful enough to cause an impact of that magnitude.
Mister Data?
Damages and injuries are minimal.
Where did it come from?
I am still checking, sir.
Hazard a guess, Mister Data.
It appears to originate from the Pegos Minor sector.
That far?
Yes, sir.
Lieutenant La Forge, set coordinates for that sector. Shields at full power.
Aye, sir. Coordinates laid in.
Sir, I am receiving a transmission from Pegos Minor. It's an S.O.S.
Put it on audio, Lieutenant.

I repeat, this is Doctor Paul Manheim. We are in need of help. Urgent. Any ship please respond. Coordinates are six-six-seven eight point nine by seven-zero-seven-five-four-two point two. Manheim out.
I can't get through, Captain.
Turn it off. Lay in a course for those coordinates, La Forge. Warp eight.
Aye, sir. Plotted and laid in.
Estimated arrival four hours, seventeen minutes, thirty-five seconds.
Isn't Manheim the one who was thrown out of the Institute for unauthorized experiments?
Quite the contrary, Commander. He left of his own volition. Professor Manheim is the most highly reputed scientist within the Federation. A brilliant visionary who...
... Who disappeared over fifteen years ago. Along with his wife, Laura.
Did you know him, Captain?
No. He was teaching at the University when I was in Paris, but I never had the pleasure. Number One, you have the Conn. Inform me half an hour before we reach the coordinates.
Aye, sir.
Computer, this is Captain Picard.
What is your pleasure, Captain?
Paris. Twenty-two years ago. A warm spring day. April ninth. Eighteen hundred hours -- three o'clock.
Monsieur, welcome to Cafe Des Artistes. Is this your first time in Paris?
No, I've been here before.
That table.
Mais oui, we are here to please you.
I've been away far too long.
Some wine, some cheese, a perfect tarte tatin...
scene: 6    INT. HOLODECK - PARIS - CONTINUOUS ACTION - DAY

quote: I'm afraid I'm not hungry. I really came for the view.
scene: 6    INT. HOLODECK - PARIS - CONTINUOUS ACTION - DAY

quote: Perhaps what you hunger for is not on the menu?
scene: 6    INT. HOLODECK - PARIS - CONTINUOUS ACTION - DAY

quote: Perhaps not. It was many years ago, I had a rendezvous -- I was to meet someone, a young woman, here, at this very table.
scene: 6    INT. HOLODECK - PARIS - CONTINUOUS ACTION - DAY

quote: She did not come?
scene: 6    INT. HOLODECK - PARIS - CONTINUOUS ACTION - DAY

quote: I don't know, actually. I've always imagined that she did.
scene: 6    INT. HOLODECK - PARIS - CONTINUOUS ACTION - DAY

quote: You, however, did not. Trust Edouard. I will bring something special, just for you.
scene: 6    INT. HOLODECK - PARIS - CONTINUOUS ACTION - DAY

quote: I'm not staying if all you're going to do is talk about him.
scene: 6    INT. HOLODECK - PARIS - CONTINUOUS ACTION - DAY

quote: What is this for?
scene: 6    INT. HOLODECK - PARIS - CONTINUOUS ACTION - DAY

quote: My lunch. Feed it to the birds.
scene: 6    INT. HOLODECK - PARIS - CONTINUOUS ACTION - DAY

quote: He will come. He will.
scene: 6    INT. HOLODECK - PARIS - CONTINUOUS ACTION - DAY

quote: Yes, I'm sure he will.
scene: 6    INT. HOLODECK - PARIS - CONTINUOUS ACTION - DAY

quote: He's a military man, just like you. We're going to get married and he's going to stay here in Paris and never leave me.
scene: 6    INT. HOLODECK - PARIS - CONTINUOUS ACTION - DAY

quote: He's stationed here?
scene: 6    INT. HOLODECK - PARIS - CONTINUOUS ACTION - DAY

quote: Not yet, but that's the way I've got it planned. Last night, well, after last night, he just couldn't leave. He couldn't.
scene: 6    INT. HOLODECK - PARIS - CONTINUOUS ACTION - DAY

quote: If he's as young as you are, maybe he doesn't know yet exactly what he wants to do.
scene: 6    INT. HOLODECK - PARIS - CONTINUOUS ACTION - DAY

quote: You're an important Starfleet officer -- what would you advise my lover to do -- go off and explore the galaxy or stay here and explore something which has no boundaries -- love?
scene: 6    INT. HOLODECK - PARIS - CONTINUOUS ACTION - DAY

quote: I would tell him that he must be the person he is meant to be... and that you deserve nothing less than that.
scene: 6    INT. HOLODECK - PARIS - CONTINUOUS ACTION - DAY

quote: Bordeaux, a very passionate year.
scene: 6    INT. HOLODECK - PARIS - CONTINUOUS ACTION - DAY

quote: A glass for the young lady.
scene: 6    INT. HOLODECK - PARIS - CONTINUOUS ACTION - DAY

quote: Do I remind you of the girl you left behind?
scene: 6    INT. HOLODECK - PARIS - CONTINUOUS ACTION - DAY

quote: No. Yes, you do. It's hard to say, it has been many years.
scene: 6    INT. HOLODECK - PARIS - CONTINUOUS ACTION - DAY

quote: Then you have forgotten her face.
scene: 6    INT. HOLODECK - PARIS - CONTINUOUS ACTION - DAY

quote: Not a single detail. I can see every inch of her to this day and being here -- I can feel the softness of her in the breeze, smell the fragrance of her in the flowers. I have not forgotten.
scene: 6    INT. HOLODECK - PARIS - CONTINUOUS ACTION - DAY

quote: What was her name?
scene: 6    INT. HOLODECK - PARIS - CONTINUOUS ACTION - DAY

quote: Laura.
scene: 6    INT. HOLODECK - PARIS - CONTINUOUS ACTION - DAY

quote: You've been at that console twice as long as you estimated.
My estimation was incorrect, Captain.
And I think it would be best if what I am about to tell you were also incorrect.
Nonsense. Out with it.
Someone, I would assume Professor Manheim, opened up a window. A window into another dimension.
You don't know how?
You don't know what it is?
What came through this window?
A window, that's all you know.
Sir, the answers to your questions will be the most important scientific answers of the twenty-fourth century.
Manheim.
Captain, we've reached the coordinates specified. There's nothing here.
I am receiving new coordinates. It's a relay signal, the same source as the first one.
Set course for the new coordinates.
Aye, sir.
Why would someone make it this difficult to find him if he truly wants to be found?
A failsafe, I would imagine.
Captain, my sensors are picking up what appears to be a small planet.
Mister La Forge, standard orbit. Give me a visual.
Aye, sir.
Viewscreen on.
There's a forcefield of some kind surrounding the planet, sir.
Penetrable?
No, sir.
Open hailing frequencies.
Hailing frequencies open, sir.
This is the USS Enterprise responding to your signal for help.
Help. Please help me. I don't know what to do. It's only the two of us. He's shaking. Please.
Can you lock onto her coordinates?
No, sir. The forcefield is preventing any kind of contact other than audio.
Mrs. Manheim, this is... the captain of the Enterprise. Is your husband conscious?
No. You've got to help him.
There's a force field surrounding your planet.
Yes. I know.
Good. Then you must be very brave and leave his side long enough to shut down the system that is preventing us from helping you.
Good. Lock onto their coordinates and beam them up.
I'd like extra decontamination precautions, Captain.
Fine, Number One.
The professor seems to be going in and out of consciousness.
Well, the first time he's "in" be sure you find out what the hell he was up to down there.
Is anything wrong, sir?
No.
Jean-Luc?
Laura.
It's not good.
When will I be able to question him?
I don't know.
Is he dead?
No. I've sedated him.
I'll do everything I can to save him.
Doctor, we need to talk to this man as soon as we can.
I'll let you know as soon as he regains consciousness.
Thank you. Thank you, all.
Bridge, Picard. Status report.
Shields are holding, Captain. Ten percent loss of power. Minimal damage, all decks.
We can't wait for this man to wake up to find out what's going on here. Clearly, whatever this window is, it's still open.
Agreed, Captain. I'll have Data start immediately on a thorough evaluation of all of Doctor Manheim's theories.
Head gone. Must fill up. It's in the cross!
When did this start?
Right before he sent out the S.O.S. -- after he -- well, he'd been in the lab for at least three days.
Laura, I'm afraid I need to ask you a number of questions - and time is of the essence.
You can use my office.
This is not how I imagined it.
Nor I.
You've done well. Exactly as you'd hoped.
Not exactly. Nothing works just as you hope... Laura, I'm sorry about your husband. I need some information from you.
I don't know what I can tell you, Jean-Luc. At best, I'm a glorified laboratory assistant. Paul's mental capabilities are so far beyond yours and mine, he couldn't discuss his work with me.
But you must know something of the nature of his experiments.
He lectures me, he practices on me, but he doesn't confide in me. I stopped listening long ago.
Why did he come here? Why Vandor?
He said it was because it was far enough away, no one would or could steal his theories... or stop him from trying to prove them.
What he was working on is unquestionably quite dangerous as well as out of control.

He's a little like you, Jean-Luc. He loves, he needs the challenges of the unknown... all I do know is that he's been very close to a major breakthrough. He's been excited and agitated and working around the clock for the past few months.
Why weren't you affected?
Every time he began an experiment, he insisted I stay in what he said was a protected room. I guess he was right.
Fifteen years here? By yourself?
There was no place left for Paul to go -- and I am his wife. Our destiny isn't always exactly what we expect. Isn't that what you just said?
I must send a team to the planet.
You can't. It's protected. Paul's made sure no one can get in.
Excuse me.
Is he worse?
He's resting. I'd like to have you undergo some tests as well.
He'll start them.
Thank you for your kindness, Doctor.
She's an old friend.
I gathered that. It's her husband I'm more concerned with at the moment.
What's his prognosis?
So far, he's dying and there's nothing I can do about it. His entire genetic structure is altering -- constantly. I don't know how or why. I've never encountered anything like it before.
How long does he have?
Maybe a couple of days. It's not predictable. All I can do is attempt to maintain him until we find out what's causing the damage.
Can I talk to him?
You may never be able to talk to him. He may never be coherent again.
Doctor.
I haven't seen Mrs. Manheim since Paris.
You needn't explain, Captain.
It was a very long time ago.
Yes. She's a lovely woman.
Were you able to get any information, sir?
Mrs. Manheim is in the dark about her husband's work. And he may never come out of the state he's in. What have you found out?
Sensors show there's an immense volume of energy being reflected from a small point on the planet's surface... near the main Laboratory.
Reflecting what?
We do not know yet, sir. It appears to be moving from a thin beam into wider beams and back again in an unstructured manner.
Is this "beam" responsible for the jolt we just felt?
Not directly, sir. It is possible the beam is responsible for opening the "window."
But that's pure assumption. We still know virtually nothing about Manheim's work.

About this particular work, sir. Professor Manheim is renowned for his work in perfecting subspace communications, and thermodynamics, but those particular achievements seem to have no bearing on what he is trying to do on Vandor.
To the point, Mister Data.
When he disappeared fifteen years ago, he had been working on theories of non-linear time. His colleagues apparently questioned his obsession -- and his methodology.
How far did he get?
No one knows. He became angry about their doubts that he could enter other dimensions. He left the Institute. That is the last anyone heard of him until now.
Can we deal with what's happening down there from the ship?
Unlikely. I would need to see the Doctor's notes. And even then, his mind is of such unparalleled brilliance, I am not sure I could decipher them.
There is an elaborate defense system to protect his work.
We can get through any system.
It's worth a try.
Agreed. Take a small away team. See what you can find down there.
Worf. Data.
Energize.
I don't care if you have a signal or not -- bring them back!
They will return. Please, they've got to.
I have a reading, it's not much, not complete...
... Lock on, man. Beam them back!
Medical Emergency Team in Transporter Sixteen.
Good God, what happened out there?
One at a time.
Stop! I'll wait for Lieutenant Worf.
I'm all right!
I'll see you all in my Ready Room.
A dragon?
Not exactly, sir, but a monster that...
... It wasn't anything at all like that. It was beautiful -- godlike.
It was completely logical in the most disorganized way possible. Colors, sounds, lights. Not light you see, but light you feel.
You each experienced something different and it affect you in dissimilar ways.
Sir, Worf is a warrior. He probably confronted his dragon and fought with it. Professor Manheim also tried to analyze whatever it is that comes through this window. They were both struck down.
I experienced it.
I observed.
However interesting this may be, it is not, as far as I can tell, bringing us any closer to closing that damn window.
Check and re-check all the sensor readings that were taken while you were "out there."
Yes, sir.
Number One, are you clear-headed enough to do some research?
Yes, sir.
Good, then go over all the material that Mister Data collected on Manheim's various theories. Maybe you'll be able to see something that ties in. Something that explains the experience you just had.
Yes, Captain.
Lieutenant Worf... go to your quarters and rest...
... I feel fine, Captain.
That's an order. There will be plenty of "dragons" left when you awaken.
Yes, sir.
This has nothing to do with their subconscious fears and dreams?
I'm afraid not, sir. This is real.
That's what I was afraid you'd say, Counselor.
Where am I?
Thank God. We're on the USS Enterprise. They answered your distress signal.
I sent an S.O.S.?
Yes. Oh, Paul, you're going to be fine.
I'm not fine, Laura. I'm not even close to fine.
Always remember this one thing...
Professor Manheim is conscious.
Remember... It was worth it. What happened, what will happen, all of it. It was all worth it.
The Board was right. We should have stayed at the Institute.
Then you never would have seen your Picard.
What are you talking about?
Fate.
But, how could you know, I never told you about Jean-Luc?
I know more things now than I could have learned in twenty lifetimes. And one of the things I know is that you, my darling, belong with him. It's your destiny.
Laura, don't you understand, none of that's important now. I've been on the other side!
Doctor Manheim, please try to stay calm. There are many questions we need to ask you.
Professor Manheim.
Captain Picard.
We need your help. The situation is not good.
And I need yours. My body seems to be in poor physical condition. I need you to go down to the planet and collect my notes, my calculations.
We intend to. What exactly were you working on when this window to another dimension was opened?
How were you able to determine that?
We are not totally without resources.
I'll speak to the Science Officer.
Lieutenant Commander Data at your service, Professor.
I have spent the last twenty years struggling with time/gravity theories.
I suspected it but I could not be sure.
There is one security system after another on your way down to the planet.
We had the privilege of running into one of them when we tried to beam down.
What about time/gravity?
It's all in my notes.
I'd rather hear it from you personally, a condensed version.
There is hardly a condensed version of the most complex theory of the twenty-fourth century, Captain Picard, but if you insist, I'll attempt one that even you will be able to understand.

A star four light years away went nova. I have been able to mathematically... "latch" onto the incredible gravity of this smooth back globe and direct that energy, that nearly immeasurable force, into space.
So -- this energy, directed into space, then what?
Then, abracadabra, Captain Picard, we all see God! A window to another dimension, isn't that how you put it? So pedestrian.
Fine. My scientific knowledge isn't the issue here -- yours is. You opened it. Are you brilliant enough to close it?
Give me thirty cc's of trisinov. I'll give you the correct coordinates to beam safely to Vandor and the electrical codes you'll need to bypass security systems to get into my lab.

I'm sorry Captain, my powers appear to be quite useless in this particular instance. Whatever Professor Manheim is going through is to feelings what white is to color. I cannot distinguish one feeling from another. They are all there.
Certainly hostility.
It would seem he has reason to feel hostile to you, sir, his wife...
Yes, Counselor, let's stick to the important issues. Lieutenant Worf.
Yes, sir?
I want every heading that Manheim gave Mister Data checked out and then rechecked. No one's beaming down to Vandor until we can be reasonably sure they'll make it through.
Right away, sir.
I'll be in my quarters, Number One.
Everything's under control, Captain.
He has had a great emotional shock. This, coupled with the strain of command, is wearing on him.
Women!
I would think that someone who has so recently seen God would be a little more... well...
... No one ever said that God didn't have a sense of humor.
Did you ever hear the one about...
You saved it. All these years.
I wondered when you would come.
You are so beautiful, my throat feels as if it will close and I will never be able to tell you how beautiful you truly are.
My love, why didn't you come to meet me that last day in Paris?
Fear. Fear of losing you. Fear of staying and losing myself.
Not a day went by that I didn't look up into the sky and will you to know...
... to know that I loved you still. I always did and Jean-Luc, I always will.
My love. I cannot live without you.
I'll never leave you again.
Who are you?
I'm Doctor Crusher and I'm trying...
Imposter! Touch me and you touch whatever your head can't understand. I am real. You are illusion.
Try to rest.
I am rest. I am action. I am you. Imposter.
I wish I could talk to you -- Professor Manheim. I bet you were really something.
